segments.text: Vice President for Development, Texas A&M University Campus.
Dear Bob, Please allow me to use this letter to record on paper at least a summary of my conversation this morning with Dr. N.A.
McNeil.
Paragraph.
I met him
According to our agreement at the Ramada Inn, soon after breakfast, he seemed to be both physically and intellectually a bit older than when you and I last saw him up at his home near Moody.
And when I chatted with him to record his recollections of his days here a few months after that, I gave him a copy of the letter, which is, I gave him the letter in which I attempted to
describe the probable cost to outline the, in which I attempted to outline the work involved in publishing his materials and the probable total cost.
of publishing his recollections of service in the CBI theater during World War II.
Paragraph.
He, Dr. McNeil, also gave me copies of
his recollections from his student days, his teaching in high school, and his many years of service here.
He indicated that he would, quote, like to have them published also, period, quote.
The most important
impression I received from this conversation was that he seemed to be assuming that he was giving us the privilege of having a copy of all of his recollections
and that he would give A&M the publication rights to those.
No mention, he made no mention of the possibility of his contributing the cost
of publication or any of all of these materials and I did not bring that subject up either.
He, paragraph, Dr. McNeil mentioned two or three times that he thought that
A printed version of these materials might sell, quote, at least a thousand copies, period, quote.
He did not ask me my opinion on that subject, nor did I offer any observations.
However, I would be very skeptical that such a sales total could be achieved.
Paragraph
I wanted to pass this information on to you as soon as possible because I fear that this could become a delicate matter.
When I finished the conversation with him, I told him that I would communicate with you as soon as possible about our conversation.
and would make you aware of his passing copy of the materials on to me.
Thus, I want to use this letter to fulfill that commitment, to indicate a fulfillment of that commitment, and to turn to you for advice as to what any other
effort I should give to this comparatively delicate matter.
Sincerely, end of letter.
These fine recollections describe your service in the Far East during the Second World War.
and I join with you in the hope that they can be published.
After discussing these materials with a friend who has a good deal of experience with such matters,
understand from him that the editing of this material, preparation of all these pages for publication,
and the printing of a small book of 500 copies could be done for the total cost of $12,500.
Paragraph.
Please do not...
Please do not assume that this letter is a contractual commitment on behalf of Texas A&M, but I understand that from this conversation that the sum of $12,500 or less would be the cost of
preparation and publication of these pages.
The person to whom I turned for advice on this matter did not offer any recommendations regarding distribution and or sales
of the 500 copies.
He did emphasize that the cost to print a small number, 50 to 100 copies, was very little different from printing 500 copies.
Paragraph, am I correct in assuming, am I correct in understanding that the quote memoir quote was the only material that you hoped to be printed at this time?
Paragraph, if I can assist further with this or any, assist you further with this or any other

matter please let me know sincerely put it me and my title copy to dr. Robert Walker in the letter 125th anniversary celebration of Texas A&M the celebrating the 125th anniversary of Texas A&M I assume that you will be one of those 25

greatest Aggies quote quotes around greatest Aggies thus this interview will be the basis for for a portion of that manuscript the only additional effort that might be required is that I want to ask all of those interviewees especially about
What, now in retrospect, what did they learn here at Texas A&M that has been important in their life since they left this campus?
In other words, what did it mean to be, to you, to be an Aggie?
And then the final question of most of my interviews would be used in this manuscript also.
what feelings do you have about for Texas A&M today?
Paragraph.
But in conclusion, let me thank you for all of your help to this institution and particularly with this effort to record your memories and preserve them for all time to come.
Sincerely, end of letter.
This is a note to Dennis Corrington.
Director, Texas Department of Recreational Sports, Texas A&M University campus MS4250.
Dear Dennis, thank you for a splendid interview.
It was really good.
And I am deeply grateful for your time.
Most of all, however, I am grateful for the very
effective manner in which you described the development of the fine programs now here that started as intramurals and are now recreational sports.
I am deeply grateful to you, sincerely.
End of letter.
We provide you before very long
In the meantime, I hope that you will call upon me whenever I can assist.
I would be proud to do so.

We are determined to make the Heritage Preservation Program a collection, a treasure house of information so that the future leaders of Texas A&E University can benefit from the experience of this institution's past.
Let's send this same letter to Mr. Patterson also.
End of letter.
I've missed seeing you for far too long.
Thank you again for all you have meant to me.
Sincerely, end of letter.
This letter to Porter S. Garner, Jr.
361 Englewood, E-N-G-L-E-W-O-O-D, Englewood Drive, Kerrville, Texas, 78028.
Dear Mr. Garner, thank you for a splendid interview, paragraph.
I deeply appreciate your contributing your time.
and your special memories of Texas A&M to our effort to preserve as much as we can of the accurate recollections of how this great institution came to be what it is.
My visit with you was a special step in this
continuing effort and I thank you for your assistance.
Paragraph.
Now I'm looking forward to a similar session with your son.
It might be fun in the future to compare the Aggie years for the two of you.
paragraphs and again my appreciation sincerely, end of letter.
This letter to Mr. Edwin C. Garner, 307 Dexter Drive, College Station, Texas.
Don't have his zip, it's in the red phone book.
Dear Mr. Garner, what a delightful
visit you provided for me and for the Heritage Preservation Program.
Your interview was one of the most informative and enjoyable of the 90 that I have conducted so far.
Please allow me to use this note to record my deep personal appreciation
and to assure you that we will proudly place your memories in the files of the Heritage Preservation Program.
As I hope I mentioned, we will provide you with a first typed copy of the interview as soon as possible.
At that time we hope you will review it, adding additional information as well as making corrections of any errors of fact.
Paragraph, again let me thank you for your kindness and for the splendid
enjoyment I received from that conversation with you.
Sincerely, end of letter.
This letter to Dr. Melvin L. Greenhut, 5814 Constellation Circle, Rockwall, Texas 75032.
Dear Mel, thank you for your letter and your interest
in being a contributor to the Heritage Preservation Program, which is our way of trying to preserve as much as we can about how Texas A&M developed into the splendid institution that it is today.
paragraph, please let me first respond to your inquiry about schedule in a comparatively fuzzy manner.
Our youngest child, John, is getting married at the Highland Park Presbyterian Church on
Saturday, so we will be busy with that event and its aftereffects until Monday.
Then I will be up in Missouri from May 23 through the 29th.
My wife will be in North Carolina the first week in June.
After that, finally, things will calm down a bit.
So please give me a reprieve, and I will get back to you in mid-June to see when we might work out something.
In the meantime, if you planned, please let me know when you plan to be down here and might have three hours unscheduled and we could do the recorded interview here.
On the other hand, I would be pleased to have an excuse to drive up to the Metroplex and come over to Rockwall
and do the conversation there, but it will have to wait until after mid-June.
Paragraph, in the meantime, I send you greetings and hope that all is going well for you.
Sincerely, end of letter.
